repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

Both `byte2line(1)` and `line2byte(1)` return -1 if the buffer's memline is uninitialized.

### Solution

Add a check in `ml_find_line_or_offset` that serves to cover both cases.

Closes #34199.

Note that #34199 is currently marked as a documentation bug. I think the docs are actually fine as they are, and that the issue should be resolved by fixing `byte2line` and `line2byte` (see [this](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199#issuecomment-2915573674) comment for my reasoning).

comment_regular_data.body: You really refuse to respect #25369, do you?

I don't think that's related. That issue was about not being able to detect the difference between an empty buffer and a buffer with a newline.

This PR wouldn't revert that, it just changes the output of:

```
touch empty
echo > newline
printf ' ' > space
for f in empty newline space; do
  nvim --headless --clean -c 'echo bufname() nvim_buf_get_offset(0,0) line2byte(line("$")+1) "\n"' -c q $f
done
```

from:

```
empty 0 -1
newline 0 2
space 0 3
```

to

```
empty 0 1
newline 0 2
space 0 3
```

This is just about the behavior of `byte2line` and `line2byte` wrt uninitialized memlines, it has nothing to do with newlines.

Hmm, however the treesitter change isn't right. `line2byte(1) == 1` is true on any buffer with a single line.

Also please do not add test cases to test/old/, unless you submit this change to Vim.

> line2byte(1) == 1 is true on any buffer with a single line.

Yeah you're right.

I'm actually not sure how to check if a buffer is empty. Like, I think `api.nvim_buf_get_offset(bufnr, 1) == 1` would also be true on a buffer with a single character that has both `eol` and `fixeol` turned off.

> Also please do not add test cases to test/old/

Should I move them somewhere else or just delete them?

I tested this PR and `line2byte(line('$') + 1)` still returns -1 on an empty buffer, so you can use that.

The tests (and probably including the one in `api/buffer_spec.lua`) can be moved to `test/functional/vimscript/buf_functions_spec.lua`.

> line2byte(line('$') + 1) still returns -1 on an empty buffer

But only if it's never been edited. This fails at the last assertion (also on master):

```lua
local is_empty = function(bufnr)
  return vim.api.nvim_buf_call(bufnr, function()
    return vim.fn.line2byte(vim.fn.line("$") + 1) == -1
  end)
end

local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)

assert(is_empty(bufnr))
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, 0, 0, 0, 0, { "a" })
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_text(bufnr, 0, 0, 0, 1, {})
assert(is_empty(bufnr))
```

Like suggested, I'm now checking for an empty buffer with:

```lua
api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr) == 1
       and api.nvim_buf_call(bufnr, function()
         return vim.fn.line2byte(2) == -1
       end)
```

Which, while not always correct because of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34216#issuecomment-2917861616, is incorrect in exactly the same cases the old check was, so it shouldn't introduce any regressions.

> The tests [..] can be moved to [..]

Done.
Is there anything left to do here?

Why shouldn't these return 0 for an empty buffer? Related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272, which I see you also opened.

It's good that you are thinking about this carefully, and we want to nail down the semantics. But we need to be clear about what semantics we actually want. Neither the description here, nor in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199 , are clear to me about why 1 is the correct result for these functions on an empty buffer. 

My current thoughts:

- We definitely don't want arbitrarily different behavior for a "uninitialized" buffer, since that is just an internal implementation detail (unless we are talking about "unloaded" buffers).
- An *empty* buffer seems like a meaningful distinction. Returning 1 for an empty buffer seems wrong.

Ideally, I think these vim script functions should not diverge from upstream vim if we can avoid it. we already introduced a separate API function for _one_ of these because we needed a different behavior for new plugins without needing to confuse existing plugins. If this is really fixing a bug (as opposed to "I would prefer if it worked this other way"), I think it should be sent upstream to vim. We can of course disagree with their decision (instead of introducing the _other_ API function), but asking the question at vim/vim is still worth it.

> Why shouldn't these return 0 for an empty buffer? [..] Returning 1 for an empty buffer seems wrong

Both `byte2line` and `line2byte` are 1-indexed, so e.g. `line2byte(1)` returning `1` is the same as `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` returning `0`.

> We can of course disagree with their decision (instead of introducing the other API function)

Even if this gets fixed on the vim side, I think it would still be beneficial to have an `nvim_buf_*` equivalent for `byte2line`.

> Both `byte2line` and `line2byte` are 1-indexed, so e.g. `line2byte(1)` returning `1` is the same as `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` returning `0`.

There is no "byte", so indexing to the first item (which doesn't exist) does not make sense.

As @zeertzjq mentioned https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199#issuecomment-2914419439 , 

> Whether a buffer is empty is not an internal state, and it has nothing to do with the `'eol'` option.

See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34199#issuecomment-2955987169

Test case:

```lua
vim.cmd[[edit test.txt]]
assert(-1 == vim.fn.line2byte(1))
assert(-1 == vim.fn.byte2line(1))
vim.api.nvim_input('ifoo<esc>u')
-- Fails: returns [1, 1]
vim.schedule(function()
  assert(-1 == vim.fn.line2byte(1))
  assert(-1 == vim.fn.byte2line(1))
end)
```

> There is no "byte", so indexing to the first item (which doesn't exist) does not make sense.

Right, I'm used to thinking about text positions in terms of offsets rather than indices, and 0 is a valid offset in an empty buffer.

However `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` returns 0, so are we saying that an empty buffer has 0 bytes but 1 line? If so, then `line2byte(1)` should return 1 and `byte2line(1)` should return -1.

> However `nvim_buf_get_offset(0, 0)` returns 0, so are we saying that an empty buffer has 0 bytes but 1 line? If so, then `line2byte(1)` should return 1 and `byte2line(1)` should return -1

An empty buffer has zero lines and zero bytes.

We can go in two directions. If we are going to change anything, I suggest improving "correctness", so more cases to return -1 (or whatever signals an empty buffer) when the buffer is indeed empty.

And I gave a full repro, unlike the current tests in this PR.

This isn't the right direction, see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34272#issuecomment-2972877283 . Either we need to "fix" undo so it correctly returns the buffer to a fully "empty" state, or document this clearly (or find the existing docs :)

labels.description: upstream issue that must be fixed in Vim first
labels.name: needs:vim-patch

title: fix(eval): make `byte2line` and `line2byte` work with empty memline
